title: Inelastic collisions - kinetic energy of pucks

content.question: A puck of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> slides with speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> toward a stationary puck of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, as shown. Friction between the pucks and the surface is negligible. The pucks collide and stick together. Which of the following correctly describes the change in the kinetic energy of the two-puck system during the collision?

choices.label: It decreases by <math alttext="one third m times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.
It decreases by <math alttext="m times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.

It increases by <math alttext="one third m times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.
It increases by <math alttext="m times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: It decreases by <math alttext="one third m times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.
